instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3023: What is 820-3023? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> random crashing
threads.message:
Arrived with 3 beeps. no liquid damage. Customer said it was very hot just before the beeping started.  Reflowed ram to solve that issue. After customer had it for a few days it came back with report of random crashing/freezing with distortion/lines in the screen.

Passed full EFI Apple ASD.

Is there anything else to check on this? We haven't been able to reproduce the problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> random crashing
threads.message: Probably a PCH or CPU issue if RAM reflow didn't hold up. Total time waster.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> random crashing
threads.message:
Is it worth it to try and reflow CPU or PCH, or recommended just to refund??

Still boot into OSX no problem

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> random crashing
threads.message: You can run Unigine Valley test to try and replicate the issues. Most of time, 3 beeps on these older 2011 boards ends up being a PCH or internal trace issue, so RAM reflow is not always a for sure fix on them like newer ones.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> random crashing
threads.message:
Reballing 16 RAM chips and finally end with CPU issue, or broken trace, is not the best time investment here.
You can try now to reflow CPU with quality flux too, to burn eventually crap underneath.
But do not expect miracles from any reflow...
